title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdos Problem #1060**

Let f(n) count solutions to k·σ(k) = n, where σ(k) is the sum of divisors.

**Questions:**
1. Is f(n) ≤ n^{o(1/log log n)}?
2. Perhaps even f(n) ≤ (log n)^{O(1)}?

**References:**
- Guy [Gu04] Problem B11
- OEIS A327153
mathContext: The sum of divisors function σ(k) = Σ_{d|k} d is multiplicative. The product k·σ(k) combines multiplicative and additive structure.

title: Sum of Divisors
content:
**sigma:**

Sum of divisors function σ(k) = sum of all divisors of k.

```lean
abbrev sigma (k : N) : N := (Nat.divisors k).sum id
```

**Examples:**
- σ(1) = 1
- σ(6) = 1+2+3+6 = 12
- σ(p) = p+1 for prime p

title: σ(1) = 1
content:
**sigma_one:**

The only divisor of 1 is 1 itself, so σ(1) = 1.

```lean
theorem sigma_one : sigma 1 = 1
```

title: σ(p) = p + 1 for primes
content:
**sigma_prime:**

For prime p, the only divisors are 1 and p, so σ(p) = 1 + p.

```lean
theorem sigma_prime (p : N) (hp : p.Prime) : sigma p = p + 1
```

title: Product Function g(k)
content:
**g:**

The product function g(k) = k · σ(k).

```lean
def g (k : N) : N := k * sigma k
```

This is the central function of the problem. The question is: how many k give g(k) = n?

title: Solution Set
content:
**solutionSet:**

The set of k such that k·σ(k) = n.

```lean
def solutionSet (n : N) : Set N := {k : N | g k = n}
```

This set is what we count to get f(n).

title: Counting Function f(n)
content:
**f:**

f(n) = number of solutions to k·σ(k) = n.

```lean
noncomputable def f (n : N) : N := (solutionSet n).ncard
```

This is the main object of study. The conjectures bound f(n).

title: Finiteness of Solutions
content:
**solutionSet_finite:**

The solution set is finite for any n > 0.

**Proof idea:**
- σ(k) ≥ 1 for all k > 0 (since 1 | k)
- Therefore k·σ(k) ≥ k
- So if g(k) = n, then k ≤ n

This means we only need to check finitely many k.
mathContext: This finiteness is crucial for f(n) to be well-defined as a natural number.

title: Weak Conjecture
content:
**erdos_1060_weak_conjecture:**

f(n) ≤ n^{o(1/log log n)} as n → ∞.

This means: for any ε > 0, eventually f(n) ≤ n^{ε/log log n}.

```lean
axiom erdos_1060_weak_conjecture :
    forall ε > 0, exists N, forall n > N,
      f n ≤ n ^ (ε / log (log n))
```

This is a very slow growth rate - slower than any fixed power of n.
mathContext: The double-logarithmic decay means f(n) grows extremely slowly compared to any polynomial.

title: Strong Conjecture
content:
**erdos_1060_strong_conjecture:**

f(n) ≤ (log n)^C for some constant C.

```lean
axiom erdos_1060_strong_conjecture :
    exists C, forall n > 1, f n ≤ (log n) ^ C
```

This is much stronger - polynomial in log n rather than a slow power of n.
mathContext: A polylogarithmic bound would be a dramatic improvement over the weak conjecture.

title: OEIS A327153
content:
**oeis_A327153:**

The set of n for which f(n) > 0 (i.e., k·σ(k) = n has a solution).

```lean
def oeis_A327153 : Set N := {n : N | f n > 0}
```

This is the range of the function g(k) = k·σ(k).

title: Example: g(2) = 6
content:
**Example:**

n = 6: k = 2 gives 2·σ(2) = 2·3 = 6.

```lean
example : g 2 = 6
```

Verified by native_decide.

title: Prime Examples
content:
**Prime examples:**

For prime p, g(p) = p(p+1):
- g(5) = 30
- g(7) = 56

This gives infinitely many values in the range of g.
